isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - SPEEDOMETER/TACHOMETER DIAGNOSTICS AND SERVICE - PROGRAMMING - 9800 MODEL

svcsubproc.title: January 1996 and Later - Electronic Engines
svcsubproc.para: The speedo/tach cluster has two sets of DIP switches with ten switches in each bank. The DIP switches are located at the top, rear of the cluster and can be used to manually program the speedo/tach microprocessor to receive data link signals generated by the engine Electronic Control Module (ECM) ( Figure 21).
Information on engine, axle ratio, tire revolutions per mile, number of teeth on the transmission speedometer gear, etc. are programmed into the engine ECM and not the speedo/tach module.

important.para: The original speedo/tach cluster microprocessor is electronically programmed, when the vehicle is built, to receive data link signals generated by the engine ECM. However, the physical positions of all the DIP switches remain in the "0" position.

svcsubproc.para:
The original electronically programmed settings are shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket in the 010000 code, Speedo & Misc - last twenty (20) digits ( Figure 22). DIP switch settings can also be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section.

important.para:
Physically moving any of the DIP switches from the "0" position disables all electronically programmed settings of the cluster. If any DIP switch is moved for any reason, then ALL of the DIP switches must be physically moved to the appropriate positions shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket or determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration
section. Physically moving all the DIP switches back to the "0" position, of an electronically programmed cluster, will enable the original programmed settings.

svcsubproc.para: If there are any changes in vehicle components, such as tire size or axle ratio etc., the engine ECM must be reprogrammed with correct data.

note.para: The speedo/tach module microprocessor or DIP switches do not get reprogrammed.

svcsubproc.para: An electronic service tool (EST) such as the Pro-Link 9000 or the EZ-Tech, with the authorized engine manufacturer's software must be used for reprogramming the engine ECM. Refer to the Pro-Link manual or the engine manufacturer's service literature for instructions.
If a cluster is to be replaced, the service cluster must be programmed either electronically or manually.

note.para: An electronic service tool (EST) such as the Pro-Link 9000, with the Instrument Panel Cartridge Kit or the EZ-Tech, with the instrument cluster software, are used to program the speedometer/tachometer module microprocessor, through the J1708 data link . Refer to the Pro-Link or EZ-Tech instrument cluster software manual for instructions. This method requires that all of the DIP switches be physically set in the "0" position.

svcsubproc.para: If manually programming the cluster, the DIP switches should be physically set to the positions shown on the vehicle linesetting ticket or can be determined by following the DIP Switch Configuration section below.
The physical settings of the DIP switch positions for electronic engines is as follows:
Ten Speedometer Switches - 1111111111 (All ten (10) positions on left bank).
Eight Tachometer Switches - 11111111 (First eight (8) positions on right bank).
One Odometer Switch - 0 or 1 (Number ten (10) on right bank) "0" for miles or "1" for kilometers.
